metadata.description: Phonetic sounds and connected speech patterns with level categorization

levels.beginner: Individual phonemes - easy to medium difficulty sounds that exist or have equivalents in Portuguese
levels.intermediate: Difficult phonemes (th, r) and connected speech patterns (linking, reduction, assimilation)

metadata.note: Focus on sounds problematic for Portuguese speakers

sounds.name: voiceless dental fricative

mouth_position.tongue: Place tongue tip gently between upper and lower teeth
mouth_position.teeth: Slightly apart, tongue visible between them
mouth_position.airflow: Continuous air flowing through the gap between tongue and teeth

sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers often substitute /s/, /t/, or /f/ for this sound
sounds.tip: Feel the air passing over your tongue tip. Your tongue should be visible between your teeth. Practice in front of a mirror.

sounds.name: voiced dental fricative

mouth_position.tongue: Place tongue tip gently between upper and lower teeth
mouth_position.airflow: Continuous air while vibrating vocal cords

sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers often substitute /d/ or /z/ for this sound
sounds.tip: Same position as /θ/ but ADD VOICE. Put your hand on your throat - you should feel vibration.

sounds.name: near-open front unrounded vowel
sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers often use /ɛ/ (like 'bed') or /a/ (like 'car')
sounds.tip: Open your mouth WIDER than for Portuguese 'é'. Say 'eh' but drop your jaw more.

sounds.name: near-close front unrounded vowel

mouth_position.tongue: High and front, but relaxed (not as high as /i/)

sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers often use /i/ (like 'see') making 'ship' sound like 'sheep'
sounds.portuguese_similar: Shorter and more relaxed than Portuguese 'i'
sounds.tip: Relax your tongue and make it SHORTER than Portuguese 'i'. Don't smile as much.

sounds.name: near-close back rounded vowel
sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers often use /u/ (like 'food') making 'book' sound like 'buke'
sounds.portuguese_similar: Shorter and more relaxed than Portuguese 'u'
sounds.tip: Relax your lips and make it SHORTER than Portuguese 'u'. Less lip rounding.

sounds.name: alveolar approximant (American R)

mouth_position.tongue: Curl back slightly (retroflex) without touching roof of mouth

sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers may use rolled R, tap R, or guttural R
sounds.tip: The tongue NEVER touches the roof of the mouth. Curl your tongue back but keep it floating.

sounds.name: velar nasal

mouth_position.tongue: Back of tongue touches soft palate (velum)

sounds.common_mistake: Adding /g/ after the sound: 'sing-g' or substituting /n/
sounds.portuguese_similar: Similar to 'nh' but further back in the mouth
sounds.tip: Feel the back of your tongue touch the soft palate. Don't add a /g/ at the end!

sounds.name: voiceless glottal fricative

mouth_position.airflow: Strong burst of air from throat

sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers may skip the /h/ entirely or use /r/
sounds.portuguese_similar: Like the 'r' aspirado in some Brazilian dialects
sounds.tip: Breathe out strongly like fogging up a mirror. It's just air, no friction in the mouth.

sounds.name: labio-velar approximant
sounds.common_mistake: Portuguese speakers often use /v/ instead of /w/
sounds.portuguese_similar: Like saying 'u' very quickly before a vowel
sounds.tip: Round your lips like saying 'oo' and then glide into the next vowel. NO teeth contact!

sounds.name: voiced postalveolar affricate

mouth_position.tongue: Starts touching roof of mouth behind alveolar ridge, then releases

sounds.common_mistake: May be confused with /tʃ/ (unvoiced) or pronounced too softly
sounds.portuguese_similar: Like 'dj' in 'dia' (Rio accent) or 'gi' in some dialects
sounds.tip: Like 'ch' in 'church' but WITH voice. Feel your throat vibrate.

sounds.name: voiceless postalveolar affricate

mouth_position.tongue: Starts touching roof of mouth behind alveolar ridge, then releases

sounds.common_mistake: May be confused with /ʃ/ (sh) or /dʒ/ (j)
sounds.tip: Like 'j' in 'job' but WITHOUT voice. No throat vibration.

sounds.name: schwa (mid central vowel)

minimal_pairs.difference: æ vs ə in stressed vs unstressed

sounds.common_mistake: Pronouncing unstressed vowels too clearly instead of reducing to schwa
sounds.tip: The MOST common vowel in English! It's weak, short, and in UNSTRESSED syllables.

sounds.name: voiceless postalveolar fricative

mouth_position.tongue: Raised toward palate, creating narrow channel

sounds.common_mistake: Confusing with /s/ or not rounding lips enough
sounds.tip: Like telling someone to be quiet: 'shhh!' Round your lips.

sounds.name: voiced postalveolar fricative

mouth_position.tongue: Raised toward palate, creating narrow channel

sounds.common_mistake: Using /dʒ/ instead of pure /ʒ/
sounds.tip: Like /ʃ/ but ADD voice. Feel your throat vibrate.

sounds.name: diphthong (close-mid front to near-close front)

mouth_position.tongue: Starts mid-front, glides higher and fronter

sounds.common_mistake: Not gliding - saying pure /e/ instead of the diphthong
sounds.portuguese_similar: Like 'ei' in 'lei' but starts more open
sounds.tip: START with mouth more open than Portuguese 'e', then glide to 'i' sound.

sounds.name: Consonant-Vowel Linking

mouth_position.description: The final consonant of one word connects smoothly to the initial vowel of the next word

sounds.common_mistake: Pausing between words instead of linking them smoothly
sounds.tip: Move the final consonant to the beginning of the next word. 'An apple' becomes 'a-napple'.

sounds.name: Vowel-Vowel Linking (Intrusive sounds)

mouth_position.description: A glide sound (/w/ or /j/) is inserted between two vowels at word boundaries

sounds.common_mistake: Using a glottal stop between vowels instead of linking
sounds.tip: If first word ends in /uː, oʊ, aʊ/, insert /w/. If ends in /iː, eɪ, aɪ/, insert /j/.

sounds.name: Going to → gonna (Reduction)

mouth_position.description: Function words are reduced in fast natural speech

sounds.common_mistake: Always using full forms - sounds unnatural in casual speech
sounds.portuguese_similar: Similar to contractions like 'pra' (para) in Portuguese
sounds.tip: These are SPOKEN reductions, used in casual speech. Don't write them in formal contexts.

sounds.name: Flap T / Tap T

mouth_position.tongue: Quick tap against the alveolar ridge
mouth_position.description: T and D between vowels in American English sound like a quick tap

example_phrases.audio_guide: T sounds like a quick D
T becomes a flap between vowels

minimal_pairs.difference: Both sound nearly identical in American English

sounds.common_mistake: Using a strong /t/ sound instead of the quick flap
sounds.portuguese_similar: Like the 'r' in 'caro' (single tap R) in Portuguese
sounds.tip: This is the same sound as Portuguese single 'r' between vowels. Very quick tongue tap!

sounds.name: Weak Forms (Function Words)

mouth_position.description: Function words (to, for, of, from, at, can, have, etc.) are pronounced with schwa in natural speech

sounds.common_mistake: Pronouncing all words with their strong/stressed form
sounds.portuguese_similar: Similar to how 'de' becomes 'di' in Brazilian Portuguese
sounds.tip: Content words (nouns, verbs, adjectives) keep strong pronunciation. Function words (prepositions, articles, auxiliaries) use weak forms in natural speech.
